reviews.review_text: Fantastic! I love the way it was written with so much candor. It made me wanted to hop on a plane and experience the tastes and aromas of their food. To see and smell their flowers. Truly love it and highly recommend it. Congratulations to the author.

This novel treats the taking of Istanbul during the war after the Great War. It combines a Tolstoyian epic with elements of melodramatic domestic affairs. These focus on the tumult within a family as they watch their social status and political stability dwindle. Events incorporate the breakdown of the Ottoman Empire in 1920 as Allied troops back Greek Christian forces bent on dividing up Turkey after the war, in a civil war.As this topic is little-known abroad, Kenneth J. Dakan's fluid translation from a difficult language to render easily into our own, Turkish, provides a wider audience access to entering this transition. People whom for six centuries have grown accustomed to the Sultan's rule and bureaucratic intrigue find themselves forced to rely on the promises of the nationalists, and their ambition to create a secular state which somehow remains an Islamic one, a difficult task the past century surely proves. And as recent headlines remind us, tellingly."Farewell: A Mansion in Occupied Istanbul" brings Ayse Kulin to an international readership, too. From what I can gather, her fiction aims at the bestseller list in her native country, blending history with love, as catastrophes loom. Dakan conveys the steady buildup of frayed nerves as bombings, imprisonment, torture, and espionage threaten the family of Ahmat Resat, finance minister for the Sultan. Caring for his ill nephew, rebellious Kamal who has gone into hiding back from a disastrous military loss suffered by the Turks, and dealing with the meddling British, the father of the household must cope with a bickering aunt, a weary wife, and a maid who hopes to marry Kamal once he heals. This set-up takes the first two-thirds of the novel.The last part draws Kamal out of his confines, as the Ankara-led nationalists fight back against the Greek, British, and French who try to subvert the remaining Caliphate Army as the Ottoman Empire collapses. This complexity moves the story along, although the domestic tensions dissipate somewhat as Kulin takes one key character into a different setting, only to leave that person somewhat adrift, eventually relegated off-stage. This pace falters a bit, compared to the brisk way Kulin moves the story along in the previous three-fourths.The other protagonist gives the meaning to the title, as the Sultan's machinations dwindle and the nation we know as Turkey since emerges. That'd make another great novel, if Kulin wants to continue this family saga. While less of Istanbul is seen and experienced than I'd have anticipated, the interior drama remains interesting throughout.
Great history behind this book and the story is fantastic.
love the back drop/ time period/ characters

This novel opens in 1920 Istanbul, during the last days of the Ottoman Empire.  A real page turner with a perfect blend of fiction and facts.  It is so well written - just pick it up and you can thank me later. :)

I didn't enjoy this as much as the author's "Last Train to Istanbul". However, I found the struggles of the family and their associates under the occupation quite absorbing. I fell I know a lot more about the last days of the Ottomans now.

The author in simple images captures the era and the lifestyles of people caught up in the aftermath of WW1 as it affected Istanbul. The characters emerge along with their cultural heritages.and mores. The reader experiences their confusion and varied reactions as the Ottoman Empire implodes and the occupying powers carve up the territory. I hope  that more than the current two books by this author are translated into English. They are informative as well as good reading.
Really captures the end of an empire and of a way of life...I didn't want it to end. A page turner and a great read.
Loved this book, put into perspective a complex period in Turkish history. Characters were complex and compelling set at the end of the Ottoman Empire.

summary: A sweeping story of the final collapse of the Ottoman Empire over the course of the First World War, "Farewell" is a novel of one particular family living in one particular house during these historic events.
